Announcing JUnitDoclet

This email is not about the JUnitDoclet, Robert Watkins 
announced a few month ago. It is about a new tool with 
the same name but different background. 

JUnitDoclet 1.0.1 ( http://www.junitdoclet.org/ ) does 
generate and maintain skeletons of TestCases and TestSuites 
based on the structure of your application and some 
templates. Unlike some other tools it has build-in concepts
to support refactoring. So it is very easy to keep the 
tests in sync whenever the application structure changes. 

Maybe the most significant effect of JUnitDoclet is to 
keep the developer focused on the problem. There is no 
interruption when trying to remember the syntax of a 
TestCase. ;-) With very few clicks / keystrokes the 
TestCase is there. If it is that easy, you'll find yourself 
writing more tests very soon.

Please visit http://www.junitdoclet.org/ to learn more 
about this tool. There you'll find:

 * an online demo (See it in action before you install.),
 * FAQ,
 * user feedback,
 * the article "Testing Without Excuses",
 * a download section and 
 * much more (like the JUnitDoclet from Robert Watkins) 

The downloads include examples how to integrate JUnitDoclet 
as external tool to IDEA and Eclipse as well as a more 
generic approach for other IDE's and editors. Of course 
there is a readme for installing as ANT target too. 

We believe JUnitDoclet does lower the step toward JUnit 
and relieves developers from routine work. At the same 
time, the developer stays in control. While developing 
we followed a very simple rule: 

  JUnitDoclet is standing at your side, not in your way.

If you like that, please tell others about it.

Regards,

Steffen Gemkow
